citation.article-title: Tumebacillus permanentifrigoris gen. nov., sp. nov., an aerobic, spore-forming bacterium isolated from Canadian high Arctic permafrost.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Tumebacillus permanentifrigoris sp. nov.

Tumebacillus permanentifrigoris (per.ma.nen.ti.fri′go.ris. L. part. adj. permanens permanent; L. gen. neut. n. frigoris of/from frost; N.L. gen. neut. n. permanentifrigoris from permanent frost, permafrost, referring to the isolation of the type strain from permafrost).
Has the following characteristics in addition to those given for the genus above.
Cells are non-motile, 3–3.5×0.5 μm in size, with large terminal endospores.
Forms yellow colonies on R2A plates with no growth in liquid media.
Utilizes galactose, starch, tryptone, cellobiose, lactose, trehalose, mannitol, maltose, glucose and Casamino acids as carbon sources.
Sensitive to ampicillin, streptomycin, chloramphenicol, rifampicin, erythromycin and tetracycline, but resistant to penicillin.
The temperature range for growth is 5–37 °C (optimal growth at 25–30 °C).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 53.1 mol%.
The full fatty acid profile is given in Supplementary Table S1.
The type strain, Eur1 9.5T (=DSM 18773T =JCM 14557T), was isolated from a 9-m-deep permafrost sample from the Canadian high Arctic.
